ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the fundamentals of neuroimaging.
I learned a lot about different neuroimaging techniques. I also learned how to write about scientific material better.
A surface level understanding of fMRI and other neuroimaging methods.
introduction to the physics behind MRI, MRS, PET, and several other neuroimaging techniques; scientific writing (how to write concisely and coherently)
I learned the details of fMRI, PET, and MRS, along with other imaging techniques. I expanded my knowledge on neuroimaging for cancer, epilepsy, and anxiety.
I learned about the fundamentals of various neuroimaging techniques.
I learned the biophysical basis of NMR/MRS and its applications to different disorders/cancers

After taking this course, I learned a great deal about the metabolic principles surrounding many neuronal processes. I was also able to better understand how many neuroimaging techniques work, such as fMRI or MRS, and gain a greater appreciation for how the techniques are used in practice. Additionally, I became a stronger scientific writer through the weekly synopsis that we had to write.
Understanding of concepts related to the brain and neuroimaging. Developed skills in writing, and scientific writing specifically. Also practiced presenting on scientific topics.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: It was a very well taught course.
The course delves deep into different imaging methods and analysis methods well. There is also a lot of opportunities for students to practice scientific writing.

Strengths: relatively low workload for a writing credit and interesting info
Weaknesses: unclear feedback on assignments

Strengths: content of this course was cool. Professors Hyder and Rothman are very nice, knowledgable, and experts in the field. 

Weaknesses: class is entirely taught by other students after the first lecture, which I felt severely detracted from the educational value. I feel like the point of taking a class with experts in the field is to learn from these expertsnot be required to learn the entirety of the content through student presentations (which varied greatly in quality and were extremely inconsistent). Moreover, the grading for the two papers felt very arbitrary. The midterm paper had no instructions beyond basically "write a 10 page paper based on the fundamentals we covered in class" (with no guidance on tone, style, etc.), and we did not receive feedback on this paper until a month later. The feedback was only a few sentences giving general adviceno specific comments were made on the document.

strengths: interactive class
weaknesses: a lot of overlap between lectures, student-taught so teaching quality changed based on who was teaching the class

The strengths of this course are that you learn a lot of information in an accessible way since it's taught by students. It's a great way to practice public speaking on a scientific topic. You also learn how to write about neuroimaging in a concise and precise way. There was not as much feedback on the midterm or final papers as I would expect from a WR course, but there was a lot of feedback on the weekly synopsis.
Staff was very knowledgeable and the student presentation format was very interesting.
The students basically teach the class - wish there was more lessons on the practical aspects of MRI

A strength of this course is being able to develop and write our own assessment of the weekly material (through the synopsis) and receiving feedback about how our writing could be improved. I also appreciated how Professor Hyder helped us refine our group presentations before we disseminated the information to the class. 

A weakness of the course is the lack of writing guidance given to us before we turned in our midterm and final paper. While we did receive comments on our papers after they were submitted, it would have been equally as helpful to receive robust pointers for writing papers before we started, as it is a writing style that not everyone is accustomed to. The synopsis comments did help in general, but since these papers were more involved, it would have been better to be given advice catered specifically to them.  The teaching fellows could have also been more utilized in this class by allowing them to hold informal office hours to help students with writing.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to any student interested in the theory behind neuroimaging.
I would recommend this course to another student looking to learn more about the brain and different neuroimaging methods.
I would not recommend this course to another student.

Yes, if you would like to gain an understanding of various neuroimaging techniques and their applications. There is a heavy focus on MRI, so if that's something you'd like to learn more about, this class would be great for you.
I would recommend this course to another student who wants to learn about neuroimaging in a relaxed environment.
Yes if interested in neuroimaging, even if not a premed.
NO, STAY AWAY unless youre a biomedical engineering major!

Overall, I would recommend this course to another student because it offers you a good opportunity to practice writing scientifically, and for the most part, you will receive adequate feedback on your written assignments. This course might be slightly more challenging for those who haven't taken fundamental neuroscience, biochemistry, or physics classes already, as many of the lectures cover these topics.

Yes - this is a fantastic course for developing understanding of how the brain works and how neuroimaging works specifically. I would recommend this class even to a student with a non-STEM background.
